content:
I have added a paragraph at the end of the goal section to warn people about non-coprime issues and the artificial constraint on the output.

EDIT: I have also added an example and the tag "arithmetic".

Why is this one classified as Hard ? I can get it with simply check all the k*m+r (for m the maximal given divisor) one after the other which, IMHO, look like brute forcing it. 
I suggest to down classify it to medium.

Many thanks to moderation for letting this pass with one extra newline in test 6 and TWO in test 7.
A pleasure to debug.

Fixed (including the extra ones in a few inputs as well, that didn't impact me but will probably help someone out there), but geez, people, have standards!

Hi sir, there is an issue with the last validator.
3972229 MOD 1111 = 404 not 999
Regards

I have some serious issues with this puzzle:


1. Validator 6 is not equivalent to test 6. In fact, validator 6 is the first time were the moduli are not coprimes.


2. I don't see the point of the part "and at the same time x >= any of the given m". This is (yet another) artificial constraint that one has to handle, and adding a trivial but unexpected if-statement after writing some EEA code is a painful joke.

And yes, I really dislike it when the statement speaks about something but asks to do something else. :/


3. Please change the tests/validator so that the final result and the associate modulo are always less than 2^32.
Reduced difficulty a bit by avoiding very long numbers having 18 or more digits. Now it is limited to under 2^39 more adaptable to javascript
Ok for me. Except for the "fantacy" spelling, is it a reference to something or do you mean "fantasy"?

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Very stimulating to find out the solution of the Chinese Remainders problem in case of not coprime divisors.
Solved within the input loop, using only MCD and factorization algoritms, no brute force.
For me is ok.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)
To conceptually understand CRT is already difficult. This puzzle extended the difficulty further by including non-coprime inputs.

I think "Validator 7" is the only one that really exercises the constraint "x>= any of the given m".
Without this constraint the solution  would be '1' not '61'
Not sure why you add this extra constraint. 
If you want to keep it, I suggest adding a test for it.
Alain

Damn, I already got this idea but did not undraft it in time.
There is a way to solve it without brute-forcing it, ie without the generalized Euclid algorithm. I wrote a direct solution in Python in 8 lines with no hard mathematics.

n=int(input())
R,M=0,1
for _ in range(n):
    m,r=[int(j) for j in input().split()]
    while R%m!=r:
        R+=M
    M*=m
print(R)

You can:
* add some harder cases (for example a division by 12 and a division by 16),
* add bigger divisors (for example by 10**10).
Pretty sure Validator 4 has the wrong answer.

Thank you cross-checking. There was an overflow. Now adjusted the data to fix it.
I've also cross-checked the rest to assure correctness.
Nice idea to include some composite numbers. Will also add a case with a few conditions but big divisors to make more variaties

Makes sense, and updated a test accordingly.

Getting an answer of 1 is really uninteresting, so have this rule.
Thanks your sharp eyes. Updated

Thank you finding it out there was a validator containing an unwanted non-coprime too early. Have it updated. 
Also reduced cases to within an Integer data type and still keeping the balance to make it hard to break by brute-force.
Oh, really it is. Now fixed the validator. Afterward I'd recheck my src too. Thank you
Thanks. Update was done in a hurry left behind bits of problems, and glad to see them fixed.

In the first version the limit was the max of long int which I tested would block brute forcing. Some complicated modulus and prime calculations are needed to pass.
Later the max limit was lowered to allow languages like js to process, so BF unfortunately becomes possible.
From the current usage data I feel suitable to classify it as Medium. Thanks your suggestion.
Looks good. Thanks.

I confirm that all tests/validators can now be solved with 64-bits integers. Thank you.

Moreover, test/validator 6 will reject a brute-force search.

Grrr,

it is true ... my brute force does not work ... thanks for my future headache ;)
